label: Metamorphic P–T trajectory
description:
Terms used to describe the sequence of pressure(P) – temperature(T) conditions that occurred in a given rock body over a period of time (t) of a particular metamorphic event. Also called P–T–t paths.

Definitions are largely derived from: 
a) England, PC and Richardson, SW 1977, The influence of erosion upon the mineral facies of rocks from different metamorphic environments: Journal of the Geological Society, v.134, p.201–213, doi:10.1144/gsjgs.134.2.0201)
b) England, PC and Thompson, AB 1984, Pressure-temperature-time paths of regional metamorphism I. Heat transfer during the evolution of thickened continental crust: Journal of Petrology,v.25,no.4,p.894–928)
c) Harley, 1989 (Harley, SL 1989, The origins of granulites: a metamorphic perspective: Geological Magazine,v.126,no.3,p.215–247, doi:10.1017/S0016756800022330)
d) https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pressure-temperature-time_path.

concepts.label: anticlockwise
concepts.definition: Describes the apparent direction of the sequential path on a P–T diagram, where the x-axis is temperature, and the y-axis is pressure (with positive ordinates above the abscissa). Anticlockwise P–T paths are those in which the thermal maximum (peak temperature) is reached prior to the peak pressure being attained. These P–T paths generally reflect high (geo)thermal gradient and heat flow conditions.

concepts.label: clockwise
concepts.definition: Describes the apparent direction of the sequential path on a P–T diagram, where the x-axis is temperature, and the y-axis is pressure (with positive ordinates above the abscissa). Clockwise P–T paths are those in which peak pressure is reached prior to peak temperature being attained. These P–T paths generally reflect burial and subsequent heating under low to intermediate (geo)thermal gradient and heat flow conditions.

concepts.label: isobaric
concepts.definition: Metamorphic conditions under which the pressure (P) remains constant over a period of time (t) during a metamorphic event.

concepts.label: isobaric cooling
concepts.definition: Metamorphic conditions under which the pressure (P) remains constant as temperature decreases (i.e. cooling) over a period of time (t).

concepts.label: isobaric heating
concepts.definition: Metamorphic conditions under which the pressure (P) remains constant as temperature increases (i.e. heating) over a period of time (t).

concepts.label: isothermal
concepts.definition: Metamorphic conditions under which the temperature (T) remains constant over a period of time (t), during a metamorphic event.

concepts.label: isothermal pressure decrease
concepts.definition: Metamorphic conditions under which the temperature (T) remains constant while the pressure decreases over a period of time (t).

concepts.label: isothermal pressure increase
concepts.definition: Metamorphic conditions under which the temperature (T) remains constant while pressure increases over a period of time (t).

concepts.label: near-isobaric cooling
concepts.definition: Metamorphic conditions under which the pressure (P) remains nearly constant over a period of time (t) during a metamorphic cooling event.

concepts.label: near-isobaric heating
concepts.definition: Metamorphic conditions under which the pressure (P) remains nearly constant over a period of time (t) during a metamorphic heating event.

concepts.label: near-isothermal compression
concepts.definition: Metamorphic conditions under which the temperature (T) remains nearly constant over a period of time (t) during a metamorphic compression event.

concepts.label: near-isothermal decompression
concepts.definition: Metamorphic conditions under which the temperature (T) remains nearly constant over a period of time (t) during a metamorphic decompression event.

concepts.label: unknown
concepts.definition: The pressure(P)–temperature(T)–time(t) path for a specific metamorphic event is unknown.
